g.text: polymorphisms and risk of DILI during anti-
TB treatment: a systematic review and

The aim of this study is to evaluate the potential association between
induced liver injury during anti-TB treatment (AT-DILI).
We conducted a systematic review and performed a meta-analysis to clarify the role of
Medline and EMBASE databases were searched for studies published in English to December 31, 2017, on the association between
polymorphism and AT-DILI risk. Outcomes were pooled with random-effects meta-analysis. Details were registered in
Thirty-seven studies involving 1527 cases and 7184 controls were included in this meta-analysis. The overall odds ratio (OR) of AT-
different ethnic populations, ranging from 6.42 (95% CI 2.41
= 2.3%) for the West Asian population to 2.32 (95% CI
= 80.3%) for the European population. Within the slow
associated with the highest risk of AT-DILI (OR = 1.68, 95% CI 1.09
slow acetylation was observed to increase the risk of AT-DILI in tuberculosis patients. Our results support the hypothesis that
genotype is a risk factor for AT-DILI.
